Data: Who would've thought that a series about high school girls in short skirts fighting tank battles would be the peak of military-themed anime? ― CGDCT, or “Cute Girls Doing Cute Things,” is a genre in anime that usually revolves around a high school setting where cute girls in school uniforms talk about love, discuss fashion, go shopping, share a hobby, and do other things without a single guy in sight...

Requiem of the Rose King Episode 13  by Rebecca Silverman, Apr 11th 2022                   How would you rate episode 13 of Requiem of the Rose King ?                     Community score: 3.4            I may have anticipated this week's use of Richard's final speech to Henry in Henry the Sixth Part Three in the episode twelve review, but the line “I am myself alone” still informs Richard's character a great deal. Its myriad interpretations speak to the turmoil in his heart, even if he believes that, in killing Henry, he is currently without a soul. What's interesting is that although Richard says more than once that he has killed his own soul in that final encounter with his love, there's not that noticeable a difference in his actions now. He still laments his body, feels conflicted about the crown, and is quietly working behind the scenes, though to what end even he may not be fully aware of. We know what Edward wants, what Elizabeth wants, what Buckingham wants. But what does Richard want? And has he ever really known?    It's fitting that this point in the story is when Aya Kanno's version of the plays brings in Jane Shore. In Shakespearean terms, Jane isn't a named character in any of the plays, although some productions do give her name to one of the random court ladies and she is mentioned as “Mistress Shore.” (She is, however, a significant character in several other versions of the Richard III story, including a 1714 play named after her.) Historically she was in fact Edward's mistress beginning in 1476 until his death in 1483, and while she wasn't a witch, Richard did accuse her of conspiring against him when he took the throne. Ultimately Jane did pretty well for a player in the Wars of the Roses saga, outliving basically everyone else to die in her 80s. Her status as a witch in Requiem of the Rose King, at least as we see it in this episode, is yet another marker of Richard's discomfort with his feminine aspects; he compares her to Joan (also not a witch), and she makes him similarly uncomfortable as she seeks to manipulate him for her own ends. In Richard's world, women are witches like Jane and Joan, betrayers like Anne and Cecily, or schemers like Isabelle, Margaret, and Elizabeth. Why would he want to accept that part of himself when he can't like it in others?    Jane's entry into the scene is also a good way to show us how much time has passed. Prince Edward died in 1471 and King Edward is still alive, so we have to be somewhere between 1476 and 1483, a time frame borne out by the ages of the new sons present in the episode – and Buckingham's impressive growth spurt. (And guess what? The new kids are also all Edwards and Richards!) The king's slide into debauchery and George's descent into wine-fueled anger are what allow Jane to slip in and begin manipulating circumstances as she pleases, but if we're honest she doesn't have to work that hard, because both of Richard's older brothers aren't exactly leading healthy lives. Richard's exclusion – which he basically does himself – is what gives him a better view of what's going on but also what may be keeping him safer than either Edward or George, because he's not out there in plain sight most of the time. Sure people wonder why he and Anne have only one child (and we all know who that adorable kid really is), but for the most part he's just quietly lurking.    That's what makes the opening scene of this cour so striking. It features an actor as Richard, performing the scene I mentioned in the beginning. Richard is playing a part, it implies, reciting his lines as he moves through the world still feeling the pain of Henry's loss and does what he believes is his part for his father's dream. Heaven may not be in the circlet of the crown, but Hell most definitely is, and Richard's been staring down into that abyss for a while now. Will he slip over the edge and embrace Shakespearean villainy? The curtain has risen on Richard III. Let's watch and find out. Requiem of the Rose King Episode 13  by Rebecca Silverman, Apr 11th 2022                   How would you rate episode 13 of Requiem of the Rose King ?                     Community score: 3.4            I may have anticipated this week's use of Richard's final speech to Henry in Henry the Sixth Part Three in the episode twelve review, but the line “I am myself alone” still informs Richard's character a great deal. Its myriad interpretations speak to the turmoil in his heart, even if he believes that, in killing Henry, he is currently without a soul. What's interesting is that although Richard says more than once that he has killed his own soul in that final encounter with his love, there's not that noticeable a difference in his actions now. He still laments his body, feels conflicted about the crown, and is quietly working behind the scenes, though to what end even he may not be fully aware of. We know what Edward wants, what Elizabeth wants, what Buckingham wants. But what does Richard want? And has he ever really known?    It's fitting that this point in the story is when Aya Kanno's version of the plays brings in Jane Shore. In Shakespearean terms, Jane isn't a named character in any of the plays, although some productions do give her name to one of the random court ladies and she is mentioned as “Mistress Shore.” (She is, however, a significant character in several other versions of the Richard III story, including a 1714 play named after her.) Historically she was in fact Edward's mistress beginning in 1476 until his death in 1483, and while she wasn't a witch, Richard did accuse her of conspiring against him when he took the throne. Ultimately Jane did pretty well for a player in the Wars of the Roses saga, outliving basically everyone else to die in her 80s. Her status as a witch in Requiem of the Rose King, at least as we see it in this episode, is yet another marker of Richard's discomfort with his feminine aspects; he compares her to Joan (also not a witch), and she makes him similarly uncomfortable as she seeks to manipulate him for her own ends. In Richard's world, women are witches like Jane and Joan, betrayers like Anne and Cecily, or schemers like Isabelle, Margaret, and Elizabeth. Why would he want to accept that part of himself when he can't like it in others?    Jane's entry into the scene is also a good way to show us how much time has passed. Prince Edward died in 1471 and King Edward is still alive, so we have to be somewhere between 1476 and 1483, a time frame borne out by the ages of the new sons present in the episode – and Buckingham's impressive growth spurt. (And guess what? The new kids are also all Edwards and Richards!) The king's slide into debauchery and George's descent into wine-fueled anger are what allow Jane to slip in and begin manipulating circumstances as she pleases, but if we're honest she doesn't have to work that hard, because both of Richard's older brothers aren't exactly leading healthy lives. Richard's exclusion – which he basically does himself – is what gives him a better view of what's going on but also what may be keeping him safer than either Edward or George, because he's not out there in plain sight most of the time. Sure people wonder why he and Anne have only one child (and we all know who that adorable kid really is), but for the most part he's just quietly lurking.    That's what makes the opening scene of this cour so striking. It features an actor as Richard, performing the scene I mentioned in the beginning. Richard is playing a part, it implies, reciting his lines as he moves through the world still feeling the pain of Henry's loss and does what he believes is his part for his father's dream. Heaven may not be in the circlet of the crown, but Hell most definitely is, and Richard's been staring down into that abyss for a while now. Will he slip over the edge and embrace Shakespearean villainy? The curtain has risen on Richard III. Let's watch and find out. Requiem of the Rose King Episode 13  by Rebecca Silverman, Apr 11th 2022                   How would you rate episode 13 of Requiem of the Rose King ?                     Community score: 3.4            I may have anticipated this week's use of Richard's final speech to Henry in Henry the Sixth Part Three in the episode twelve review, but the line “I am myself alone” still informs Richard's character a great deal. Its myriad interpretations speak to the turmoil in his heart, even if he believes that, in killing Henry, he is currently without a soul. What's interesting is that although Richard says more than once that he has killed his own soul in that final encounter with his love, there's not that noticeable a difference in his actions now. He still laments his body, feels conflicted about the crown, and is quietly working behind the scenes, though to what end even he may not be fully aware of. We know what Edward wants, what Elizabeth wants, what Buckingham wants. But what does Richard want? And has he ever really known?    It's fitting that this point in the story is when Aya Kanno's version of the plays brings in Jane Shore. In Shakespearean terms, Jane isn't a named character in any of the plays, although some productions do give her name to one of the random court ladies and she is mentioned as “Mistress Shore.” (She is, however, a significant character in several other versions of the Richard III story, including a 1714 play named after her.) Historically she was in fact Edward's mistress beginning in 1476 until his death in 1483, and while she wasn't a witch, Richard did accuse her of conspiring against him when he took the throne. Ultimately Jane did pretty well for a player in the Wars of the Roses saga, outliving basically everyone else to die in her 80s. Her status as a witch in Requiem of the Rose King, at least as we see it in this episode, is yet another marker of Richard's discomfort with his feminine aspects; he compares her to Joan (also not a witch), and she makes him similarly uncomfortable as she seeks to manipulate him for her own ends. In Richard's world, women are witches like Jane and Joan, betrayers like Anne and Cecily, or schemers like Isabelle, Margaret, and Elizabeth. Why would he want to accept that part of himself when he can't like it in others?    Jane's entry into the scene is also a good way to show us how much time has passed. Prince Edward died in 1471 and King Edward is still alive, so we have to be somewhere between 1476 and 1483, a time frame borne out by the ages of the new sons present in the episode – and Buckingham's impressive growth spurt. (And guess what? The new kids are also all Edwards and Richards!) The king's slide into debauchery and George's descent into wine-fueled anger are what allow Jane to slip in and begin manipulating circumstances as she pleases, but if we're honest she doesn't have to work that hard, because both of Richard's older brothers aren't exactly leading healthy lives. Richard's exclusion – which he basically does himself – is what gives him a better view of what's going on but also what may be keeping him safer than either Edward or George, because he's not out there in plain sight most of the time. Sure people wonder why he and Anne have only one child (and we all know who that adorable kid really is), but for the most part he's just quietly lurking.    That's what makes the opening scene of this cour so striking. It features an actor as Richard, performing the scene I mentioned in the beginning. Richard is playing a part, it implies, reciting his lines as he moves through the world still feeling the pain of Henry's loss and does what he believes is his part for his father's dream. Heaven may not be in the circlet of the crown, but Hell most definitely is, and Richard's been staring down into that abyss for a while now. Will he slip over the edge and embrace Shakespearean villainy? The curtain has risen on Richard III. Let's watch and find out. Requiem of the Rose King Episode 13  by Rebecca Silverman, Apr 11th 2022                   How would you rate episode 13 of Requiem of the Rose King ?                     Community score: 3.4            I may have anticipated this week's use of Richard's final speech to Henry in Henry the Sixth Part Three in the episode twelve review, but the line “I am myself alone” still informs Richard's character a great deal. Its myriad interpretations speak to the turmoil in his heart, even if he believes that, in killing Henry, he is currently without a soul. What's interesting is that although Richard says more than once that he has killed his own soul in that final encounter with his love, there's not that noticeable a difference in his actions now. He still laments his body, feels conflicted about the crown, and is quietly working behind the scenes, though to what end even he may not be fully aware of. We know what Edward wants, what Elizabeth wants, what Buckingham wants. But what does Richard want? And has he ever really known?    It's fitting that this point in the story is when Aya Kanno's version of the plays brings in Jane Shore. In Shakespearean terms, Jane isn't a named character in any of the plays, although some productions do give her name to one of the random court ladies and she is mentioned as “Mistress Shore.” (She is, however, a significant character in several other versions of the Richard III story, including a 1714 play named after her.) Historically she was in fact Edward's mistress beginning in 1476 until his death in 1483, and while she wasn't a witch, Richard did accuse her of conspiring against him when he took the throne. Ultimately Jane did pretty well for a player in the Wars of the Roses saga, outliving basically everyone else to die in her 80s. Her status as a witch in Requiem of the Rose King, at least as we see it in this episode, is yet another marker of Richard's discomfort with his feminine aspects; he compares her to Joan (also not a witch), and she makes him similarly uncomfortable as she seeks to manipulate him for her own ends. In Richard's world, women are witches like Jane and Joan, betrayers like Anne and Cecily, or schemers like Isabelle, Margaret, and Elizabeth. Why would he want to accept that part of himself when he can't like it in others?    Jane's entry into the scene is also a good way to show us how much time has passed. Prince Edward died in 1471 and King Edward is still alive, so we have to be somewhere between 1476 and 1483, a time frame borne out by the ages of the new sons present in the episode – and Buckingham's impressive growth spurt. (And guess what? The new kids are also all Edwards and Richards!) The king's slide into debauchery and George's descent into wine-fueled anger are what allow Jane to slip in and begin manipulating circumstances as she pleases, but if we're honest she doesn't have to work that hard, because both of Richard's older brothers aren't exactly leading healthy lives. Richard's exclusion – which he basically does himself – is what gives him a better view of what's going on but also what may be keeping him safer than either Edward or George, because he's not out there in plain sight most of the time. Sure people wonder why he and Anne have only one child (and we all know who that adorable kid really is), but for the most part he's just quietly lurking.    That's what makes the opening scene of this cour so striking. It features an actor as Richard, performing the scene I mentioned in the beginning. Richard is playing a part, it implies, reciting his lines as he moves through the world still feeling the pain of Henry's loss and does what he believes is his part for his father's dream. Heaven may not be in the circlet of the crown, but Hell most definitely is, and Richard's been staring down into that abyss for a while now. Will he slip over the edge and embrace Shakespearean villainy? The curtain has risen on Richard III. Let's watch and find out. The ANN Aftershow The Best Spring 2022 Anime Premieres!  by Lynzee Loveridge & James Beckett, Apr 13th 2022            The Best Spring 2022 Anime Premieres!   Lynzee and James break down the most promising anime premieres this season from rom-coms to action-packed executioners! Also get the latest updates about the anime dubbing industry and why you need to put Sonic 2 and Everything, Everywhere All at Once on your must-watch list.    Make sure to tune into the ANN Aftershow live on YouTube on Mondays at 6pm PT/9pm ET!    Subscribe via:     RSS     iTunes    Stitcher icon  Stitcher     Spotify     GooglePodcasts    Meet the Hosts!   As executive editor of Anime News Network, Lynzee Loveridge has the unique position of knowing what's tracking with the critics and with viewers in the anime fandom. She not only writes her own reviews every season but also reads everything from ANN's editorial staff! Outside of work, she's just a magical girl living in a Junji Ito world.    James Beckett is one of ANN's resident series reviewers and he's never shy to let the world know how he really feels. You can find his impressions of the latest shows in the Preview Guide and well as episode reviews for hit anime series.    Jacki Jing is ANN's lead video producer and resident punch 'em up fangirl. You can find her binge-watching the latest shonen battle royale series, kicking ass on Twitch, and hosting events from esports to voice actor interviews.     Watch the full video here:      Or listen to or download the audio only podcast version here:    00:00 Intro 06:10 Reminiscing about Sonic the Hedgehog 15:00 Everything, Everywhere All at Once is one of the best movies of the year 21:00 Is remote work ending for anime dubs? 30:00 Some of the best new premieres: SPY x FAMILY, Kaguya-sama Season 3, Love After World Domination, Shikimori's Not Just a Cutie, Science Fell in Love, So I Tried to Prove It, Birdie Wing -Golf Girls' Story-, The Executioner and Her Way of Life, In the Heart of Kunoichi Tsubaki     If you like the show, be sure to write us up a review over on iTunes!    Have questions for the ANN Aftershow hosts? Tweet 'em to @ANN_Lynzee! As executive editor of Anime News Network, Lynzee Loveridge has the unique position of knowing what's tracking with the critics and with viewers in the anime fandom. She not only writes her own reviews every season but also reads everything from ANN's editorial staff! Outside of work, she's just a magical girl living in a Junji Ito world.    James Beckett is one of ANN's resident series reviewers and he's never shy to let the world know how he really feels. You can find his impressions of the latest shows in the Preview Guide and well as episode reviews for hit anime series.    Jacki Jing is ANN's lead video producer and resident punch 'em up fangirl. You can find her binge-watching the latest shonen battle royale series, kicking ass on Twitch, and hosting events from esports to voice actor interviews. James Beckett is one of ANN's resident series reviewers and he's never shy to let the world know how he really feels. You can find his impressions of the latest shows in the Preview Guide and well as episode reviews for hit anime series.    Jacki Jing is ANN's lead video producer and resident punch 'em up fangirl. You can find her binge-watching the latest shonen battle royale series, kicking ass on Twitch, and hosting events from esports to voice actor interviews. The ANN Aftershow The Best Spring 2022 Anime Premieres!  by Lynzee Loveridge & James Beckett, Apr 13th 2022            The Best Spring 2022 Anime Premieres!   Lynzee and James break down the most promising anime premieres this season from rom-coms to action-packed executioners! Also get the latest updates about the anime dubbing industry and why you need to put Sonic 2 and Everything, Everywhere All at Once on your must-watch list.    Make sure to tune into the ANN Aftershow live on YouTube on Mondays at 6pm PT/9pm ET!    Subscribe via:     RSS     iTunes    Stitcher icon  Stitcher     Spotify     GooglePodcasts    Meet the Hosts!   As executive editor of Anime News Network, Lynzee Loveridge has the unique position of knowing what's tracking with the critics and with viewers in the anime fandom. She not only writes her own reviews every season but also reads everything from ANN's editorial staff! Outside of work, she's just a magical girl living in a Junji Ito world.    James Beckett is one of ANN's resident series reviewers and he's never shy to let the world know how he really feels. You can find his impressions of the latest shows in the Preview Guide and well as episode reviews for hit anime series.    Jacki Jing is ANN's lead video producer and resident punch 'em up fangirl. You can find her binge-watching the latest shonen battle royale series, kicking ass on Twitch, and hosting events from esports to voice actor interviews.     Watch the full video here:      Or listen to or download the audio only podcast version here:    00:00 Intro 06:10 Reminiscing about Sonic the Hedgehog 15:00 Everything, Everywhere All at Once is one of the best movies of the year 21:00 Is remote work ending for anime dubs? 30:00 Some of the best new premieres: SPY x FAMILY, Kaguya-sama Season 3, Love After World Domination, Shikimori's Not Just a Cutie, Science Fell in Love, So I Tried to Prove It, Birdie Wing -Golf Girls' Story-, The Executioner and Her Way of Life, In the Heart of Kunoichi Tsubaki     If you like the show, be sure to write us up a review over on iTunes! Really, Really Love You GN 1   Apr 22, 00:00                 manga    No way he gets 100 girlfriends, right? The thing is, you're thinking about this premise with logic, and logic has no home in this manga. This manga runs off of pure, lovestruck insanity. ― Now I know what you're probably thinking, just from looking at that title. 100? Really? That's obviously some hyperbolic number meant to pull you in, right? There's no way any series could actually introduce a hund...                    column          3 comments       This Week in Anime - What the Hell is Going On in Estab Life?   Apr 21, 21:00 3 comments                 anime    Estab Life: Great Escape defies explanation. A penguin Eastern bloc, a slime girl obsessed with underpants, and not an iota of sense in sight. Steve and Nick try to make sense of this entertainingly incoherent mess of a show. ―  Estab Life: Great Escape defies explanation. A penguin Eastern bloc, a slime girl obsessed with underpants, and not an iota of sense in sight. Steve and Nick try to make sens...                    news          12 comments       New Shaman King Anime Gets Sequel   Apr 21, 18:25 12 comments                 anime    Hana, other new characters teased ― The new television anime of Hiroyuki Takei's Shaman King manga ended on Tuesday with an ad announcing that a sequel has been green-lit. The commercial spot and accompanying visuals tease Hana — the son of Yoh and Anna — as well as other new characters. The two "Thank-You visuals" show the characters now and seven years later (with Hana in the second visual). Takei ...                    news          17 comments       Xenoblade Chronicles 3 Switch RPG's Trailer Reveals July 29 Release   Apr 21, 07:16 17 comments                 games    Video previews story, characters, battle system ― Nintendo began streaming the second trailer for it and Monolith Software's Xenoblade Chronicles 3, the latest installment in the Xenoblade Chronicles role-playing game series, and it reveals that the game will launch for Nintendo Switch on July 29. This is earlier than its originally scheduled release window of September. The video previews the story,...                    news          29 comments       Netflix Considers Low-Cost Streaming Tier With Ads, After 1st Drop in Subscribers in a Decade   Apr 21, 07:15 29 comments                 industry    Service lost 200,000 subscriptions in Q1 2022, projects loss of 2 million more in Q2 ― Netflix CEO Reed Hastings said on Tuesday that the company is considering introducing an ad-supported streaming tier at a lower subscription cost. Hastings said, "Those that have followed Netflix know that I've been against the complexity of advertising and a big fan of the simplicity of subscription. But as much a...                    review                Catch These Hands! GN 1   Apr 21, 00:00                 manga    Two former delinquents cross paths again in adulthood. Their rough-and-tumble days of excitement are far in the past but maybe a new kind of excitement is awaiting them? ― An obvious element of the appeal of murata's Catch These Hands is one of contrast—that despite the nominally rough-and-tumble subject matter, the story contained within is actually adorable and sweet as hell. Apr 19, 21:00 23 comments                 anime    Kenichi Sonoda's musclehead getaway driver Bean Bandit is the subject of a recent crowdfunding campaign for a new anime short, 30 years after he appeared in Riding Bean. Jean-Karlo and Nicky evaluate how both anime hold up, warts and all. ―  Kenichi Sonoda's iconic characters make up some of the biggest hits of the 80s and 90s, from Bubblegum Crisis to Gunsmith Cats. GN 1   Apr 19, 00:00 1 comment                 manga    This is by and large an extremely familiar story – but that doesn't mean it can't be a good one if told well, and through this first volume, this series is a firmly charming riff on the formula. ― Stop me if you've heard this one before: a mopey, socially anxious teenager just can't find the courage to make friends. They're kind and friendly at heart, but feel like an outcast from others who make fri...                    interview                I Want to Hold Aono-kun So Badly I Could Die Live-Action Star Shori Sato   Apr 18, 21:00                 live-action    This isn't Shori Sato's first role in a live-action adaptation of a pop culture work, but his role as the eponymous Aono-kun is something a little different– he's a ghost. Forum - View topicNEWS: Crunchyroll Reveals Tomodachi Game Anime's English Dub Cast, April 19 Premiere             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        KitKat1721    Joined: 03 Feb 2015 		    Posts: 714       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:29 pm            Yeah, unfortunately I think I'll just be skipping dubs this season if it's all local. No shame to anyone who doesn't care, you all deserve to watch something you enjoy however you want. But personally I have zero interest in supporting such a backwards move that will only hurt the industry moving forward (given how much CR licenses and dubs, it's naive to say otherwise). It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things. And even if an individual dub may sound great, artificially cutting your talent pool so drastically only hurts the industry and the season as a whole, end of story.   And fwiw, it's not even about Dani Chambers having another major role in the same season or whatever, that kinda stuff comes in waves all the time even with remote recording and even the JPN side isn't immune to it either (current record I remember is Yuma Uchida with three or four lead roles in one season). Plus there are actors getting cast like Ben Balmaceda or Josh Bangle who are new to getting major roles, which is always a good thing.    It's that most voice recording from ADR, video games (even AAA), original animation, etc... is still allowing a variety of in-studio + remote recording, but CR/Sony does not want to for a multitude of reasons that have nothing to do with making a better product. And I just can't support that even if I have watched and enjoyed dubs alongside subs for years prior.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3941       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:44 pm            That's a pretty solid, in-house, cast but it would've been cool if they had used remote-recording to have Wendee Lee as Manabu for a shared Conan casting-gag. Then again they didn't use the Kirito gag for Kamui in Full Dive, I guess I'm not surprised.      Back to top                  MarshalBanana    Joined: 31 Aug 2014 		    Posts: 4549       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:05 pm              KitKat1721 wrote:     It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things.           I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.      Back to top                    Vizo    Joined: 19 May 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:19 pm            This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.       Back to top                  KitKat1721    Joined: 03 Feb 2015 		    Posts: 714       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 5:00 pm              MarshalBanana wrote:       KitKat1721 wrote:     It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things.           I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.           Oh for sure, I'm not naive enough to think my choices would matter. The sudden shift has just been really sad to see as someone who's always wanted that side of the industry to grow and improve for the better, and it actually was until now. And I know it's kind of a silly thing to admit considering there are definitely bigger problems in the anime industry, but it's more exhausting than it's worth to care about something and feel like no one else really does (because they either don't care about dubs already or they're happier that they're getting them faster), so it's easier on me to just step away and just watch subs for now from CR if I don't like what they're doing. I also want voice actors to be better paid, but anime is a business.  Crunchyroll is going to keep making the great majority of its dubs non-union in Dallas. I believe the return of timely simuldubs is more related to relaxed COVID restrictions.      Back to top                   Cardcaptor Takato    Joined: 27 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 3811       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:24 pm              KitKat1721 wrote:    Yeah, unfortunately I think I'll just be skipping dubs this season if it's all local. No shame to anyone who doesn't care, you all deserve to watch something you enjoy however you want. But personally I have zero interest in supporting such a backwards move that will only hurt the industry moving forward (given how much CR licenses and dubs, it's naive to say otherwise). It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things. And even if an individual dub may sound great, artificially cutting your talent pool so drastically only hurts the industry and the season as a whole, end of story.        It's your own choice to not support them but speaking as someone who's not too thrilled with Crunchyroll's decision either, I don't think it's helpful or fair to punish the TX voice cast for a decision Sony made that's out of their hands until they're able to unionize. Meanwhile until they do the TX talent still has jobs to do and their own families to feed.  And if you're going to abandon Crunchyroll dubs because of the corporate politics but continue watching subs, you should also consider those Japanese anime studios that overwork and underpay their animation staff as well.  Just this season we have Dance Dance Danseur being done by MAPPA who is one of the more infamous Japanese studios known for their mistreatment of their staff yet lots of anime fans will probably watch it whether subbed or dubbed.      Back to top                  lossthief  		     		    ANN Reviewer  Joined: 14 Dec 2012 		    Posts: 1012       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:35 pm              Cardcaptor Takato wrote:       It's your own choice to not support them but speaking as someone who's not too thrilled with Crunchyroll's decision either, I don't think it's helpful or fair to punish the TX voice cast for a decision Sony made            If we want to talk "not helpful or fair" I'd say framing Kitkat's personal and individual choice to not watch these dubs as "punishing" the actors involved qualifies a lot more. If somebody decides they don't want to eat at Chick-fil-a, they're not punishing their local franchise's minimum wage workers by not patronizing it. Kitkat even went out of their way to say they're not directing anyone else to do the same.      Back to top                  Cardcaptor Takato    Joined: 27 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 3811       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:58 pm              lossthief wrote:       If we want to talk "not helpful or fair" I'd say framing Kitkat's personal and individual choice to not watch these dubs as "punishing" the actors involved qualifies a lot more. If somebody decides they don't want to eat at Chick-fil-a, they're not punishing their local franchise's minimum wage workers by not patronizing it. Kitkat even went out of their way to say they're not directing anyone else to do the same.         I don't think Chickfila is analogous because in the case of Chickfila your money directly goes to the corporation.  In the case of anime dubs, voice actors are paid by the number of lines they do (which there should be better standards than that) and not by your streaming numbers.  Whether you watch it subbed or dubbed, the voice actors and studio staff are already paid and whether you watch it or not doesn't really effect it other than maybe the streaming numbers. Forum - View topicNEWS: Crunchyroll Reveals Tomodachi Game Anime's English Dub Cast, April 19 Premiere             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        KitKat1721    Joined: 03 Feb 2015 		    Posts: 714       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:29 pm            Yeah, unfortunately I think I'll just be skipping dubs this season if it's all local. No shame to anyone who doesn't care, you all deserve to watch something you enjoy however you want. But personally I have zero interest in supporting such a backwards move that will only hurt the industry moving forward (given how much CR licenses and dubs, it's naive to say otherwise). It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things. And even if an individual dub may sound great, artificially cutting your talent pool so drastically only hurts the industry and the season as a whole, end of story.   And fwiw, it's not even about Dani Chambers having another major role in the same season or whatever, that kinda stuff comes in waves all the time even with remote recording and even the JPN side isn't immune to it either (current record I remember is Yuma Uchida with three or four lead roles in one season). Plus there are actors getting cast like Ben Balmaceda or Josh Bangle who are new to getting major roles, which is always a good thing.    It's that most voice recording from ADR, video games (even AAA), original animation, etc... is still allowing a variety of in-studio + remote recording, but CR/Sony does not want to for a multitude of reasons that have nothing to do with making a better product. And I just can't support that even if I have watched and enjoyed dubs alongside subs for years prior.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3941       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:44 pm            That's a pretty solid, in-house, cast but it would've been cool if they had used remote-recording to have Wendee Lee as Manabu for a shared Conan casting-gag. Then again they didn't use the Kirito gag for Kamui in Full Dive, I guess I'm not surprised.      Back to top                  MarshalBanana    Joined: 31 Aug 2014 		    Posts: 4549       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:05 pm              KitKat1721 wrote:     It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things.           I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.      Back to top                    Vizo    Joined: 19 May 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:19 pm            This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.       Back to top                  KitKat1721    Joined: 03 Feb 2015 		    Posts: 714       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 5:00 pm              MarshalBanana wrote:       KitKat1721 wrote:     It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things.           I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.           Oh for sure, I'm not naive enough to think my choices would matter. The sudden shift has just been really sad to see as someone who's always wanted that side of the industry to grow and improve for the better, and it actually was until now. And I know it's kind of a silly thing to admit considering there are definitely bigger problems in the anime industry, but it's more exhausting than it's worth to care about something and feel like no one else really does (because they either don't care about dubs already or they're happier that they're getting them faster), so it's easier on me to just step away and just watch subs for now from CR if I don't like what they're doing.      Back to top                  ItsATM    Joined: 22 Jan 2021 		    Posts: 5       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 5:12 pm              Vizo wrote:    This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.        How has Spy x Family, The Executioner, Kaguya-Sama, Komi season 2, and quite a few others not caught your attention? Lots of good stuff this spring lol      Back to top                  Angel M Cazares   Subscriber   Joined: 23 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 4937 		    Location: Iscandar 		        Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 6:16 pm            So going forward the norm is going to be to condemn Crunchyroll every time they annonce non-union dubs.  I also want voice actors to be better paid, but anime is a business.  Crunchyroll is going to keep making the great majority of its dubs non-union in Dallas.     Vizo wrote:    This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.       I believe the return of timely simuldubs is more related to relaxed COVID restrictions.      Back to top                   Cardcaptor Takato    Joined: 27 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 3811       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:24 pm              KitKat1721 wrote:    Yeah, unfortunately I think I'll just be skipping dubs this season if it's all local. No shame to anyone who doesn't care, you all deserve to watch something you enjoy however you want. But personally I have zero interest in supporting such a backwards move that will only hurt the industry moving forward (given how much CR licenses and dubs, it's naive to say otherwise). It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things. And even if an individual dub may sound great, artificially cutting your talent pool so drastically only hurts the industry and the season as a whole, end of story.        It's your own choice to not support them but speaking as someone who's not too thrilled with Crunchyroll's decision either, I don't think it's helpful or fair to punish the TX voice cast for a decision Sony made that's out of their hands until they're able to unionize. Meanwhile until they do the TX talent still has jobs to do and their own families to feed.  And if you're going to abandon Crunchyroll dubs because of the corporate politics but continue watching subs, you should also consider those Japanese anime studios that overwork and underpay their animation staff as well.  Just this season we have Dance Dance Danseur being done by MAPPA who is one of the more infamous Japanese studios known for their mistreatment of their staff yet lots of anime fans will probably watch it whether subbed or dubbed.      Back to top                  lossthief  		     		    ANN Reviewer  Joined: 14 Dec 2012 		    Posts: 1012       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:35 pm              Cardcaptor Takato wrote:       It's your own choice to not support them but speaking as someone who's not too thrilled with Crunchyroll's decision either, I don't think it's helpful or fair to punish the TX voice cast for a decision Sony made            If we want to talk "not helpful or fair" I'd say framing Kitkat's personal and individual choice to not watch these dubs as "punishing" the actors involved qualifies a lot more. If somebody decides they don't want to eat at Chick-fil-a, they're not punishing their local franchise's minimum wage workers by not patronizing it. Kitkat even went out of their way to say they're not directing anyone else to do the same.      Back to top                  Cardcaptor Takato    Joined: 27 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 3811       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:58 pm              lossthief wrote:       If we want to talk "not helpful or fair" I'd say framing Kitkat's personal and individual choice to not watch these dubs as "punishing" the actors involved qualifies a lot more. If somebody decides they don't want to eat at Chick-fil-a, they're not punishing their local franchise's minimum wage workers by not patronizing it. Kitkat even went out of their way to say they're not directing anyone else to do the same.         I don't think Chickfila is analogous because in the case of Chickfila your money directly goes to the corporation.  In the case of anime dubs, voice actors are paid by the number of lines they do (which there should be better standards than that) and not by your streaming numbers.  Whether you watch it subbed or dubbed, the voice actors and studio staff are already paid and whether you watch it or not doesn't really effect it other than maybe the streaming numbers. Forum - View topicNEWS: Crunchyroll Reveals Tomodachi Game Anime's English Dub Cast, April 19 Premiere             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        KitKat1721    Joined: 03 Feb 2015 		    Posts: 714       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:29 pm            Yeah, unfortunately I think I'll just be skipping dubs this season if it's all local. No shame to anyone who doesn't care, you all deserve to watch something you enjoy however you want. But personally I have zero interest in supporting such a backwards move that will only hurt the industry moving forward (given how much CR licenses and dubs, it's naive to say otherwise). It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things. And even if an individual dub may sound great, artificially cutting your talent pool so drastically only hurts the industry and the season as a whole, end of story.   And fwiw, it's not even about Dani Chambers having another major role in the same season or whatever, that kinda stuff comes in waves all the time even with remote recording and even the JPN side isn't immune to it either (current record I remember is Yuma Uchida with three or four lead roles in one season). Plus there are actors getting cast like Ben Balmaceda or Josh Bangle who are new to getting major roles, which is always a good thing.    It's that most voice recording from ADR, video games (even AAA), original animation, etc... is still allowing a variety of in-studio + remote recording, but CR/Sony does not want to for a multitude of reasons that have nothing to do with making a better product. And I just can't support that even if I have watched and enjoyed dubs alongside subs for years prior.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3941       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:44 pm            That's a pretty solid, in-house, cast but it would've been cool if they had used remote-recording to have Wendee Lee as Manabu for a shared Conan casting-gag. Then again they didn't use the Kirito gag for Kamui in Full Dive, I guess I'm not surprised.      Back to top                  MarshalBanana    Joined: 31 Aug 2014 		    Posts: 4549       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:05 pm              KitKat1721 wrote:     It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things.           I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.      Back to top                    Vizo    Joined: 19 May 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:19 pm            This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.       Back to top                  KitKat1721    Joined: 03 Feb 2015 		    Posts: 714       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 5:00 pm              MarshalBanana wrote:       KitKat1721 wrote:     It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things.           I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.           Oh for sure, I'm not naive enough to think my choices would matter. The sudden shift has just been really sad to see as someone who's always wanted that side of the industry to grow and improve for the better, and it actually was until now. And I know it's kind of a silly thing to admit considering there are definitely bigger problems in the anime industry, but it's more exhausting than it's worth to care about something and feel like no one else really does (because they either don't care about dubs already or they're happier that they're getting them faster), so it's easier on me to just step away and just watch subs for now from CR if I don't like what they're doing.      Back to top                  ItsATM    Joined: 22 Jan 2021 		    Posts: 5       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 5:12 pm              Vizo wrote:    This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.        How has Spy x Family, The Executioner, Kaguya-Sama, Komi season 2, and quite a few others not caught your attention? Lots of good stuff this spring lol      Back to top                  Angel M Cazares   Subscriber   Joined: 23 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 4937 		    Location: Iscandar 		        Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 6:16 pm            So going forward the norm is going to be to condemn Crunchyroll every time they annonce non-union dubs.  I also want voice actors to be better paid, but anime is a business.  Crunchyroll is going to keep making the great majority of its dubs non-union in Dallas.     Vizo wrote:    This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.       I believe the return of timely simuldubs is more related to relaxed COVID restrictions.      Back to top                   Cardcaptor Takato    Joined: 27 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 3811       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:24 pm              KitKat1721 wrote:    Yeah, unfortunately I think I'll just be skipping dubs this season if it's all local. No shame to anyone who doesn't care, you all deserve to watch something you enjoy however you want. But personally I have zero interest in supporting such a backwards move that will only hurt the industry moving forward (given how much CR licenses and dubs, it's naive to say otherwise). It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things. And even if an individual dub may sound great, artificially cutting your talent pool so drastically only hurts the industry and the season as a whole, end of story.        It's your own choice to not support them but speaking as someone who's not too thrilled with Crunchyroll's decision either, I don't think it's helpful or fair to punish the TX voice cast for a decision Sony made that's out of their hands until they're able to unionize. Meanwhile until they do the TX talent still has jobs to do and their own families to feed.  And if you're going to abandon Crunchyroll dubs because of the corporate politics but continue watching subs, you should also consider those Japanese anime studios that overwork and underpay their animation staff as well.  Just this season we have Dance Dance Danseur being done by MAPPA who is one of the more infamous Japanese studios known for their mistreatment of their staff yet lots of anime fans will probably watch it whether subbed or dubbed.      Back to top                  lossthief  		     		    ANN Reviewer  Joined: 14 Dec 2012 		    Posts: 1012       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:35 pm              Cardcaptor Takato wrote:       It's your own choice to not support them but speaking as someone who's not too thrilled with Crunchyroll's decision either, I don't think it's helpful or fair to punish the TX voice cast for a decision Sony made            If we want to talk "not helpful or fair" I'd say framing Kitkat's personal and individual choice to not watch these dubs as "punishing" the actors involved qualifies a lot more. If somebody decides they don't want to eat at Chick-fil-a, they're not punishing their local franchise's minimum wage workers by not patronizing it. Kitkat even went out of their way to say they're not directing anyone else to do the same.      Back to top                  Cardcaptor Takato    Joined: 27 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 3811       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:58 pm              lossthief wrote:       If we want to talk "not helpful or fair" I'd say framing Kitkat's personal and individual choice to not watch these dubs as "punishing" the actors involved qualifies a lot more. If somebody decides they don't want to eat at Chick-fil-a, they're not punishing their local franchise's minimum wage workers by not patronizing it. Kitkat even went out of their way to say they're not directing anyone else to do the same.         I don't think Chickfila is analogous because in the case of Chickfila your money directly goes to the corporation.  In the case of anime dubs, voice actors are paid by the number of lines they do (which there should be better standards than that) and not by your streaming numbers.  Whether you watch it subbed or dubbed, the voice actors and studio staff are already paid and whether you watch it or not doesn't really effect it other than maybe the streaming numbers.      Back to top                  Vizo    Joined: 19 May 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Tue Apr 19, 2022 1:45 pm              ItsATM wrote:       Vizo wrote:    This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs. Lots of good stuff this spring lol           While those series do seem rightfully anticipated, I have a thing for survival games and action/thrillers in general. Title: NEWS: Crunchyroll Reveals Tomodachi Game Anime's English Dub Cast, April 19 Premiere - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: ข่าวสารและบทความของ Anime News Network ในรูปแบบภาษาไทย สามารถติดตามอ่านได้แล้วที่ DEXclub         กรุณาเข้าไปเยี่ยมชมได้ที่ news.dexclub.com เพื่อติดตามอ่านข่าวสารล่าสุดในรูปแบบภาษาไทย          Anime News Network's news and articles are available in Thai from DEXclub.         Visit news.dexclub.com for all the latest news in Thai.              Forum - View topicNEWS: Crunchyroll Reveals Tomodachi Game Anime's English Dub Cast, April 19 Premiere             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        KitKat1721    Joined: 03 Feb 2015 		    Posts: 714       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:29 pm            Yeah, unfortunately I think I'll just be skipping dubs this season if it's all local. No shame to anyone who doesn't care, you all deserve to watch something you enjoy however you want. But personally I have zero interest in supporting such a backwards move that will only hurt the industry moving forward (given how much CR licenses and dubs, it's naive to say otherwise). It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things. And even if an individual dub may sound great, artificially cutting your talent pool so drastically only hurts the industry and the season as a whole, end of story.   And fwiw, it's not even about Dani Chambers having another major role in the same season or whatever, that kinda stuff comes in waves all the time even with remote recording and even the JPN side isn't immune to it either (current record I remember is Yuma Uchida with three or four lead roles in one season). Plus there are actors getting cast like Ben Balmaceda or Josh Bangle who are new to getting major roles, which is always a good thing.    It's that most voice recording from ADR, video games (even AAA), original animation, etc... is still allowing a variety of in-studio + remote recording, but CR/Sony does not want to for a multitude of reasons that have nothing to do with making a better product. And I just can't support that even if I have watched and enjoyed dubs alongside subs for years prior.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3941       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:44 pm            That's a pretty solid, in-house, cast but it would've been cool if they had used remote-recording to have Wendee Lee as Manabu for a shared Conan casting-gag. Then again they didn't use the Kirito gag for Kamui in Full Dive, I guess I'm not surprised.      Back to top                  MarshalBanana    Joined: 31 Aug 2014 		    Posts: 4549       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:05 pm              KitKat1721 wrote:     It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things.           I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.      Back to top                    Vizo    Joined: 19 May 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:19 pm            This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs. I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.           Oh for sure, I'm not naive enough to think my choices would matter. The sudden shift has just been really sad to see as someone who's always wanted that side of the industry to grow and improve for the better, and it actually was until now. And I know it's kind of a silly thing to admit considering there are definitely bigger problems in the anime industry, but it's more exhausting than it's worth to care about something and feel like no one else really does (because they either don't care about dubs already or they're happier that they're getting them faster), so it's easier on me to just step away and just watch subs for now from CR if I don't like what they're doing. Title: NEWS: Crunchyroll Reveals Tomodachi Game Anime's English Dub Cast, April 19 Premiere - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: Forum - View topicNEWS: Crunchyroll Reveals Tomodachi Game Anime's English Dub Cast, April 19 Premiere             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        KitKat1721    Joined: 03 Feb 2015 		    Posts: 714       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:29 pm            Yeah, unfortunately I think I'll just be skipping dubs this season if it's all local. No shame to anyone who doesn't care, you all deserve to watch something you enjoy however you want. But personally I have zero interest in supporting such a backwards move that will only hurt the industry moving forward (given how much CR licenses and dubs, it's naive to say otherwise). It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things. And even if an individual dub may sound great, artificially cutting your talent pool so drastically only hurts the industry and the season as a whole, end of story.   And fwiw, it's not even about Dani Chambers having another major role in the same season or whatever, that kinda stuff comes in waves all the time even with remote recording and even the JPN side isn't immune to it either (current record I remember is Yuma Uchida with three or four lead roles in one season). Plus there are actors getting cast like Ben Balmaceda or Josh Bangle who are new to getting major roles, which is always a good thing.    It's that most voice recording from ADR, video games (even AAA), original animation, etc... is still allowing a variety of in-studio + remote recording, but CR/Sony does not want to for a multitude of reasons that have nothing to do with making a better product. And I just can't support that even if I have watched and enjoyed dubs alongside subs for years prior.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3941       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:44 pm            That's a pretty solid, in-house, cast but it would've been cool if they had used remote-recording to have Wendee Lee as Manabu for a shared Conan casting-gag. Then again they didn't use the Kirito gag for Kamui in Full Dive, I guess I'm not surprised.      Back to top                  MarshalBanana    Joined: 31 Aug 2014 		    Posts: 4549       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:05 pm              KitKat1721 wrote:     It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things.           I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.      Back to top                    Vizo    Joined: 19 May 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:19 pm            This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs. I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.           Oh for sure, I'm not naive enough to think my choices would matter. The sudden shift has just been really sad to see as someone who's always wanted that side of the industry to grow and improve for the better, and it actually was until now. And I know it's kind of a silly thing to admit considering there are definitely bigger problems in the anime industry, but it's more exhausting than it's worth to care about something and feel like no one else really does (because they either don't care about dubs already or they're happier that they're getting them faster), so it's easier on me to just step away and just watch subs for now from CR if I don't like what they're doing. But personally I have zero interest in supporting such a backwards move that will only hurt the industry moving forward (given how much CR licenses and dubs, it's naive to say otherwise). It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things. And even if an individual dub may sound great, artificially cutting your talent pool so drastically only hurts the industry and the season as a whole, end of story.        It's your own choice to not support them but speaking as someone who's not too thrilled with Crunchyroll's decision either, I don't think it's helpful or fair to punish the TX voice cast for a decision Sony made that's out of their hands until they're able to unionize. Meanwhile until they do the TX talent still has jobs to do and their own families to feed.  And if you're going to abandon Crunchyroll dubs because of the corporate politics but continue watching subs, you should also consider those Japanese anime studios that overwork and underpay their animation staff as well.  Just this season we have Dance Dance Danseur being done by MAPPA who is one of the more infamous Japanese studios known for their mistreatment of their staff yet lots of anime fans will probably watch it whether subbed or dubbed.      Back to top                  lossthief  		     		    ANN Reviewer  Joined: 14 Dec 2012 		    Posts: 1012       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:35 pm              Cardcaptor Takato wrote:       It's your own choice to not support them but speaking as someone who's not too thrilled with Crunchyroll's decision either, I don't think it's helpful or fair to punish the TX voice cast for a decision Sony made            If we want to talk "not helpful or fair" I'd say framing Kitkat's personal and individual choice to not watch these dubs as "punishing" the actors involved qualifies a lot more. If somebody decides they don't want to eat at Chick-fil-a, they're not punishing their local franchise's minimum wage workers by not patronizing it. Kitkat even went out of their way to say they're not directing anyone else to do the same. Kitkat even went out of their way to say they're not directing anyone else to do the same.         I don't think Chickfila is analogous because in the case of Chickfila your money directly goes to the corporation.  In the case of anime dubs, voice actors are paid by the number of lines they do (which there should be better standards than that) and not by your streaming numbers.  Whether you watch it subbed or dubbed, the voice actors and studio staff are already paid and whether you watch it or not doesn't really effect it other than maybe the streaming numbers. Back to top                  MarshalBanana    Joined: 31 Aug 2014 		    Posts: 4549       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:05 pm              KitKat1721 wrote:     It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things.           I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.      Back to top                    Vizo    Joined: 19 May 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:19 pm            This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.       Back to top                  KitKat1721    Joined: 03 Feb 2015 		    Posts: 714       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 5:00 pm              MarshalBanana wrote:       KitKat1721 wrote:     It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things.           I very much doubt fewer people watching the dub version would send them a message that they need to do more remote recodings. But if  it's just a case of principal, then ok i get that.           Oh for sure, I'm not naive enough to think my choices would matter. The sudden shift has just been really sad to see as someone who's always wanted that side of the industry to grow and improve for the better, and it actually was until now. And I know it's kind of a silly thing to admit considering there are definitely bigger problems in the anime industry, but it's more exhausting than it's worth to care about something and feel like no one else really does (because they either don't care about dubs already or they're happier that they're getting them faster), so it's easier on me to just step away and just watch subs for now from CR if I don't like what they're doing.      Back to top                  ItsATM    Joined: 22 Jan 2021 		    Posts: 5       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 5:12 pm              Vizo wrote:    This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.        How has Spy x Family, The Executioner, Kaguya-Sama, Komi season 2, and quite a few others not caught your attention? Lots of good stuff this spring lol      Back to top                  Angel M Cazares   Subscriber   Joined: 23 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 4937 		    Location: Iscandar 		        Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 6:16 pm            So going forward the norm is going to be to condemn Crunchyroll every time they annonce non-union dubs.  I also want voice actors to be better paid, but anime is a business.  Crunchyroll is going to keep making the great majority of its dubs non-union in Dallas.     Vizo wrote:    This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.       I believe the return of timely simuldubs is more related to relaxed COVID restrictions.      Back to top                   Cardcaptor Takato    Joined: 27 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 3811       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:24 pm              KitKat1721 wrote:    Yeah, unfortunately I think I'll just be skipping dubs this season if it's all local. No shame to anyone who doesn't care, you all deserve to watch something you enjoy however you want. But personally I have zero interest in supporting such a backwards move that will only hurt the industry moving forward (given how much CR licenses and dubs, it's naive to say otherwise). It would be hypocritical to support these dubs, and then turn around and be upset when they're successful enough for CR to see no reason to change things. And even if an individual dub may sound great, artificially cutting your talent pool so drastically only hurts the industry and the season as a whole, end of story.        It's your own choice to not support them but speaking as someone who's not too thrilled with Crunchyroll's decision either, I don't think it's helpful or fair to punish the TX voice cast for a decision Sony made that's out of their hands until they're able to unionize. Meanwhile until they do the TX talent still has jobs to do and their own families to feed.  And if you're going to abandon Crunchyroll dubs because of the corporate politics but continue watching subs, you should also consider those Japanese anime studios that overwork and underpay their animation staff as well.  Just this season we have Dance Dance Danseur being done by MAPPA who is one of the more infamous Japanese studios known for their mistreatment of their staff yet lots of anime fans will probably watch it whether subbed or dubbed.      Back to top                  lossthief  		     		    ANN Reviewer  Joined: 14 Dec 2012 		    Posts: 1012       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:35 pm              Cardcaptor Takato wrote:       It's your own choice to not support them but speaking as someone who's not too thrilled with Crunchyroll's decision either, I don't think it's helpful or fair to punish the TX voice cast for a decision Sony made            If we want to talk "not helpful or fair" I'd say framing Kitkat's personal and individual choice to not watch these dubs as "punishing" the actors involved qualifies a lot more. If somebody decides they don't want to eat at Chick-fil-a, they're not punishing their local franchise's minimum wage workers by not patronizing it. Kitkat even went out of their way to say they're not directing anyone else to do the same.      Back to top                  Cardcaptor Takato    Joined: 27 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 3811       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:58 pm              lossthief wrote:       If we want to talk "not helpful or fair" I'd say framing Kitkat's personal and individual choice to not watch these dubs as "punishing" the actors involved qualifies a lot more. If somebody decides they don't want to eat at Chick-fil-a, they're not punishing their local franchise's minimum wage workers by not patronizing it. Kitkat even went out of their way to say they're not directing anyone else to do the same.         I don't think Chickfila is analogous because in the case of Chickfila your money directly goes to the corporation.  In the case of anime dubs, voice actors are paid by the number of lines they do (which there should be better standards than that) and not by your streaming numbers.  Whether you watch it subbed or dubbed, the voice actors and studio staff are already paid and whether you watch it or not doesn't really effect it other than maybe the streaming numbers.      Back to top                  Vizo    Joined: 19 May 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Tue Apr 19, 2022 1:45 pm              ItsATM wrote:       Vizo wrote:    This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs. Lots of good stuff this spring lol           While those series do seem rightfully anticipated, I have a thing for survival games and action/thrillers in general. Title: NEWS: Crunchyroll Reveals Tomodachi Game Anime's English Dub Cast, April 19 Premiere - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: This anime is the only one to catch my attention this season. I'm so glad this and others are getting dubbed so soon. This is exactly what I was hoping for with Funi & Crunchy working together again- the return of 1-2 week simuldubs.

News GKIDS to Release Nadia - The Secret of Blue Water TV Anime With 4K Restoration   posted on 2022-04-20 23:46 UTC-8 by Alex Mateo         Company to release series directed by Evangelion's Hideaki Anno on home video    GKIDS announced on Wednesday that it has acquired the North American rights for Gainax's science-fiction adventure anime Nadia - The Secret of Blue Water, and it will release the series on home video, based on a new 4K restoration.    GKIDS describes the story:   It's 1889 and people from around the globe are flocking to Paris to see scientific achievements at the Exposition Universelle despite rumors of dangers lurking in the oceans. While attending the fair, teenaged inventor Jean meets Nadia, a mysterious girl who possesses a highly sought-after crystal called Blue Water. Pursued by nefarious forces, the pair journey by sea and by sky to escape their would-be captors and to discover the secret of the crystal.   The staff featured director Hideaki Anno (Neon Genesis Evangelion, His and Her Circumstances), character designer Yoshiyuki Sadamoto (Royal Space Force - The Wings of Honnêamise, Evangelion, Summer Wars), sound director Katsunori Shimizu (Tegami Bachi: Letter Bee, Fushigi Yugi), and musical composer Shiro Sagisu (Magical Shopping Arcade Abenobashi, Evangelion).    Sentai Filmworks previously released the anime on Blu-ray Disc and DVD. The anime was previously released on video tape by Streamline Pictures, and on video tape and DVD by ADV Films. News GKIDS to Release Nadia - The Secret of Blue Water TV Anime With 4K Restoration   posted on 2022-04-20 23:46 UTC-8 by Alex Mateo         Company to release series directed by Evangelion's Hideaki Anno on home video    GKIDS announced on Wednesday that it has acquired the North American rights for Gainax's science-fiction adventure anime Nadia - The Secret of Blue Water, and it will release the series on home video, based on a new 4K restoration.    GKIDS describes the story:   It's 1889 and people from around the globe are flocking to Paris to see scientific achievements at the Exposition Universelle despite rumors of dangers lurking in the oceans. While attending the fair, teenaged inventor Jean meets Nadia, a mysterious girl who possesses a highly sought-after crystal called Blue Water. Pursued by nefarious forces, the pair journey by sea and by sky to escape their would-be captors and to discover the secret of the crystal.   The staff featured director Hideaki Anno (Neon Genesis Evangelion, His and Her Circumstances), character designer Yoshiyuki Sadamoto (Royal Space Force - The Wings of Honnêamise, Evangelion, Summer Wars), sound director Katsunori Shimizu (Tegami Bachi: Letter Bee, Fushigi Yugi), and musical composer Shiro Sagisu (Magical Shopping Arcade Abenobashi, Evangelion).    Sentai Filmworks previously released the anime on Blu-ray Disc and DVD. The anime was previously released on video tape by Streamline Pictures, and on video tape and DVD by ADV Films. Data: feature          20 comments       Why Girls und Panzer Works So Well   Apr 20, 21:00 20 comments                 anime    Who would've thought that a series about high school girls in short skirts fighting tank battles would be the peak of military-themed anime? ― CGDCT, or “Cute Girls Doing Cute Things,” is a genre in anime that usually revolves around a high school setting where cute girls in school uniforms talk about love, discuss fashion, go shopping, share a hobby, and do other things without a single guy in sight...

Visit news.dexclub.com for all the latest news in Thai.            This Week in Anime - What the Hell is Going On in Estab Life?  Estab Life: Great Escape defies explanation. A penguin Eastern bloc, a slime girl obsessed with underpants, and not an iota of sense in sight. Steve and Nick try to make sense of this entertainingly incoherent mess of a show.        Why Girls und Panzer Works So Well Who would've thought that a series about high school girls in short skirts fighting tank battles would be the peak of military-themed anime?        This Week in Anime - Does Kenichi Sonoda's Riding Bean Hold Up? Kenichi Sonoda's musclehead getaway driver Bean Bandit is the subject of a recent crowdfunding campaign for a new anime short, 30 years after he appeared in Riding Bean. Jean-Karlo and Nicky evaluate how both anime hold up, warts and all.        Hello, Melancholic! GN 1 This is by and large an extremely familiar story – but that doesn't mean it can't be a good one if told well, and through this first volume, this series is a firmly charming riff on the formula. Visit news.dexclub.com for all the latest news in Thai.            This Week in Anime - What the Hell is Going On in Estab Life?  Estab Life: Great Escape defies explanation. A penguin Eastern bloc, a slime girl obsessed with underpants, and not an iota of sense in sight. Steve and Nick try to make sense of this entertainingly incoherent mess of a show.        Why Girls und Panzer Works So Well Who would've thought that a series about high school girls in short skirts fighting tank battles would be the peak of military-themed anime?        This Week in Anime - Does Kenichi Sonoda's Riding Bean Hold Up? Kenichi Sonoda's musclehead getaway driver Bean Bandit is the subject of a recent crowdfunding campaign for a new anime short, 30 years after he appeared in Riding Bean. Jean-Karlo and Nicky evaluate how both anime hold up, warts and all.        Hello, Melancholic! GN 1 This is by and large an extremely familiar story – but that doesn't mean it can't be a good one if told well, and through this first volume, this series is a firmly charming riff on the formula.
